3. Use a revision checklist to evaluate their own draft.
4. Practice giving and receiving constructive feedback.
5. Revise based on checklist and feedback.
6. Write or type the final draft.
materials_needed: Clean paper or computer for final draft

slides.setup_instructions: Print or have the first draft ready with wide margins for notes. Prepare a revision checklist covering content, organization, evidence, and mechanics.

slides.text: Revision literally means 're-vision' — seeing again. It is not just fixing spelling errors. Professional writers revise multiple times, often changing entire sections. Today you will revise in two passes: First pass (content and organization) — Is the argument clear? Is evidence strong? Does it flow logically? Second pass (editing) — Are sentences grammatically correct? Is spelling accurate? Is punctuation proper?

Revision Checklist — Content: Does the introduction hook the reader? Is the thesis clear? Does each body paragraph have a topic sentence, evidence, and explanation? Do paragraphs connect logically with transitions? Does the conclusion restate the thesis and add a final insight? Are sources credited? If any answer is 'no,' fix it before moving to editing.

Revision Checklist — Editing: Read each sentence aloud. Does it sound right? Check for: run-on sentences (break into two), fragments (add missing subjects or verbs), subject-verb agreement, consistent tense, comma usage, and spelling. Use one colored pen for content changes and another for editing marks. Reading aloud catches errors your eyes miss.

Giving feedback: When reviewing someone else's work, start with what is working well (a strong opening, a compelling fact, clear organization). Then offer specific, constructive suggestions: 'The second paragraph could be stronger with a specific example' is helpful. 'This paragraph is bad' is not. The goal is to help the writer improve, not to criticize.

slides.prompt: Complete both passes of the revision checklist on your draft. Make content changes in one color and editing corrections in another. Then read your paper aloud — every word — and mark anything that sounds awkward or unclear. After revision, write your final draft on clean paper or type it. Include your title, all paragraphs, and your source list. Read the final version one last time to catch any remaining errors. Congratulations — you have written a research paper.

slides.text: You have taken a curious question and turned it into a complete, well-organized research paper. This process — question, outline, draft, revise — is how real writers and researchers work. The skills you practiced this week (focusing a topic, organizing evidence, drafting, revising) will serve you in every subject and throughout your education. Save your paper in your portfolio.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student distinguish between revision and editing? Does their final draft show evidence of both content revision and mechanical editing? Is the paper complete with introduction, body, conclusion, and citations?

parent_notes: Completing a research paper is a significant accomplishment for an upper elementary student. Celebrate this achievement. The revision process is where real learning happens — children often resist revision because they feel their first draft is 'done.' Emphasize that all published writers revise extensively. If your child types the final draft, it is a good opportunity to practice keyboarding skills. Save this paper in a portfolio to track writing growth over the year. If the paper has issues, remember that the process matters more than perfection at this stage. The ability to research, organize, draft, and revise is the skill; the paper itself is practice.

title: Fraction and Decimal Review — Converting and Comparing
description: Students practice converting between fractions and decimals, comparing values in both forms, and applying all fraction and decimal operations learned this week. They complete a comprehensive review that prepares them for ratio and proportion work.
instructions:
1. Review fraction-to-decimal conversion (divide numerator by denominator).
2. Review decimal-to-fraction conversion (place value method).
3. Compare fractions and decimals on a number line.
4. Practice mixed operations: add, subtract, multiply, divide fractions and decimals.
5. Solve real-world problems requiring conversion.
6. Assessment: timed practice set covering the week's skills.

slides.setup_instructions: Draw a number line from 0 to 2 with marks at every 0.1. Have a calculator available only for checking work, not for solving.

slides.text: Fractions and decimals are two ways to write the same value. To convert a fraction to a decimal, divide the numerator by the denominator: 3/4 = 3 ÷ 4 = 0.75. To convert a decimal to a fraction, use place value: 0.75 = 75/100 = 3/4. Some fractions create repeating decimals: 1/3 = 0.333... We write this as 0.3 with a bar over the 3.

To compare fractions and decimals, convert to the same form. Which is larger: 3/8 or 0.4? Convert 3/8 to decimal: 3 ÷ 8 = 0.375. Now compare: 0.375 < 0.4, so 3/8 < 0.4. Alternatively, convert 0.4 to a fraction: 0.4 = 4/10 = 2/5. Find common denominators: 3/8 = 15/40, 2/5 = 16/40. 15/40 < 16/40. Same answer, different method.

This week you learned: multiplying fractions (multiply across), dividing fractions (Keep-Change-Flip), multiplying decimals (count decimal places), and word problems requiring you to choose the right operation. These skills combine when you encounter problems mixing fractions and decimals. Strategy: convert everything to the same form before calculating.

Looking ahead: Next week we begin ratios and proportions, which build directly on fraction skills. A ratio is a comparison of two quantities (3:4 or 3/4). A proportion says two ratios are equal (3/4 = 6/8). Your fraction fluency — especially equivalent fractions and cross-multiplication — will be essential. Today's review ensures you are ready.

slides.prompt: Comprehensive Review: (1) Convert to decimals: 5/8, 7/20, 11/4. (2) Convert to fractions and simplify: 0.65, 0.125, 1.6. (3) Order from least to greatest: 3/5, 0.58, 7/12, 0.6. (4) Solve: 2/3 x 4/5, 7/8 ÷ 1/4, 3.6 x 0.25, 1 3/4 ÷ 2/3. (5) Word problem: A trail mix recipe uses 2/3 cup nuts, 0.5 cup raisins, and 3/4 cup granola. How many total cups? What fraction of the mix is nuts? Check all answers with a calculator.

slides.text: You can now move fluently between fractions and decimals, compare values in either form, and perform all four operations with both. This flexibility is a powerful mathematical tool. Next week brings ratios and proportions — a natural extension of your fraction mastery that opens doors to real-world applications like scale models, maps, and recipes.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student convert between fractions and decimals, compare values in mixed forms, and perform multiplication and division of both fractions and decimals accurately?

parent_notes: This review lesson consolidates a week of intensive fraction and decimal work. If your child struggles with any section, identify the specific skill gap and revisit that day's lesson. The conversion between fractions and decimals is particularly important because real life uses both: recipes use fractions, money uses decimals, and many problems require switching between them. The looking-ahead preview of ratios and proportions motivates continued fraction practice. If your child finds the review easy, challenge them with harder problems or have them teach a concept to you — teaching is the deepest form of learning.

title: The Reformation — Martin Luther and the 95 Theses
description: Students learn how the Renaissance spirit of questioning extended to religion through the Protestant Reformation. They study Martin Luther's grievances with the Catholic Church, the posting of the 95 Theses, and how the printing press amplified his message across Europe.
instructions:
1. Connect the Renaissance spirit of inquiry to questioning religious authority.
2. Explain the context: indulgences, Church wealth, and corruption.
3. Tell the story of Martin Luther and the 95 Theses (1517).
4. Discuss how the printing press spread Luther's ideas rapidly.
5. Examine the Reformation from multiple perspectives: Luther, the Pope, ordinary people.
6. Analyze a primary source excerpt from the 95 Theses.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a simplified excerpt from Luther's 95 Theses (3-5 theses in accessible language). Display a map of Europe showing Wittenberg, Rome, and the eventual spread of Protestantism.

slides.text: The Renaissance taught people to question, to examine evidence, and to think for themselves. It was only a matter of time before that questioning spirit reached the most powerful institution in Europe: the Catholic Church. In 1517, a German monk named Martin Luther did something that split Christianity in two and changed Europe forever.

The problem: The Catholic Church was selling indulgences — documents that claimed to reduce the time a person's soul spent in purgatory. Pay money, receive forgiveness. Johann Tetzel, a Church agent, even had a slogan: 'As soon as a coin in the coffer rings, a soul from purgatory springs.' Luther believed this was a betrayal of Christian teaching. Salvation, he argued, came from faith alone, not from payments to the Church.

On October 31, 1517, Luther nailed his 95 Theses — 95 arguments against indulgences and Church corruption — to the door of the Castle Church in Wittenberg, Germany. This was a common way to invite scholarly debate, but what happened next was unprecedented. Thanks to the printing press (invented just 60 years earlier), Luther's theses were copied, translated, and distributed across Europe within weeks. One monk's protest became a continent-wide movement.

Multiple perspectives: Luther saw himself as reforming a corrupt Church. The Pope saw Luther as a dangerous heretic threatening Church unity and authority. Ordinary people saw a chance to challenge powerful institutions that taxed them heavily. German princes saw an opportunity for political independence from Rome. The same event looked completely different depending on where you stood. This is why historians study multiple perspectives.

slides.prompt: Read the simplified 95 Theses excerpts. In your history journal, write three short responses from three different perspectives: (1) Martin Luther — why he believes his protest is necessary and righteous. (2) Pope Leo X — why he believes Luther is dangerous and wrong. (3) A German farmer — how this conflict affects ordinary people. Each response should be 3-5 sentences. Then add the Reformation to your Renaissance timeline. Finally, answer: How did the printing press make the Reformation possible?

slides.text: The Reformation shows how ideas can change the world — especially when technology (the printing press) helps spread them. Luther's protest led to the creation of Protestant churches, religious wars, and eventually the idea that individuals could interpret scripture for themselves. Next week we will see how the Reformation reshaped Europe and led to new political structures.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain what indulgences were, why Luther opposed them, and how the printing press amplified the Reformation? Can they articulate at least two different perspectives on the event?

parent_notes: The Reformation is a sensitive topic involving religious disagreement. Frame it as a historical event, not a judgment on any faith tradition. Help your child see that both sides had reasons for their positions — Luther genuinely believed the Church was betraying its principles, while Church leaders genuinely feared the chaos of individuals interpreting scripture alone. The multiple perspectives activity is crucial for developing historical thinking. The connection to the printing press is powerful: technology amplifying ideas is a timeless pattern (think of social media today). If your family is Catholic, Protestant, or another denomination, this is a wonderful opportunity to share your own faith tradition's perspective on these events.

title: Elements and Compounds — How Atoms Combine
description: Students learn how atoms bond together to form compounds and molecules. They explore the difference between elements, compounds, and mixtures, understand chemical formulas, and model simple molecules like water (H2O) and carbon dioxide (CO2).
instructions:
1. Review atoms and elements from previous lessons.
2. Define compound: two or more elements chemically bonded.
3. Explain chemical formulas: what H2O and CO2 mean.
4. Distinguish compounds from mixtures.
5. Build molecular models of common compounds.
6. Discuss how compounds have different properties from their component elements.

slides.heading: Elements and Compounds
slides.subheading: How Atoms Combine to Make New Substances

slides.setup_instructions: Assign clay colors to common elements: white for hydrogen, red for oxygen, black for carbon, blue for nitrogen. Have toothpicks ready for bonds between atoms.

slides.text: An element is a pure substance made of only one type of atom — all gold, or all oxygen. A compound is a substance made of two or more different elements chemically bonded together. Water (H2O) is a compound: two hydrogen atoms bonded to one oxygen atom. The subscript number tells you how many atoms of each element. No subscript means one atom.

Here is the amazing thing about compounds: they have completely different properties from the elements that make them. Sodium (Na) is a shiny metal that explodes in water. Chlorine (Cl) is a poisonous green gas. But combine them and you get sodium chloride (NaCl) — ordinary table salt! Hydrogen is a flammable gas, oxygen supports burning, but water (H2O) puts out fires. Chemical bonding creates entirely new substances.

Compound vs. mixture: In a compound, elements are chemically bonded and cannot be easily separated. In a mixture, substances are physically combined and can be separated. Salt water is a mixture — you can boil off the water and get the salt back. But water itself is a compound — you cannot easily separate the hydrogen from the oxygen without a chemical reaction. Trail mix is a mixture; a cookie is more like a compound.

Common compounds to know: Water (H2O) — 2 hydrogen + 1 oxygen. Carbon dioxide (CO2) — 1 carbon + 2 oxygen (what you exhale). Glucose (C6H12O6) — sugar (6 carbon + 12 hydrogen + 6 oxygen). Sodium chloride (NaCl) — table salt. Carbon monoxide (CO) — dangerous gas (1 carbon + 1 oxygen). Notice how CO and CO2 differ by just one oxygen atom, yet one is deadly and the other is harmless.

slides.prompt: Build clay models of these molecules: Water (H2O) — 2 white hydrogen balls connected to 1 red oxygen ball in a V shape. Carbon dioxide (CO2) — 1 black carbon ball with 2 red oxygen balls on either side in a line. Methane (CH4) — 1 black carbon with 4 white hydrogen balls arranged around it. In your science journal, draw each model, write its formula, and list one property of the compound. Then answer: Why is CO2 different from CO even though they contain the same elements?

slides.text: Atoms combine to form compounds with entirely new properties. The chemical formula tells you exactly what atoms are present and in what quantities. Understanding compounds explains everything from why water puts out fire to why your body needs glucose for energy. Next week we will explore what happens when compounds break apart and reform — chemical reactions.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student distinguish between elements, compounds, and mixtures? Can they read a chemical formula and identify the elements and number of atoms present?

parent_notes: The compound vs. mixture distinction often confuses students. Use kitchen examples: a salad is a mixture (you can pick out the tomatoes), but a cake is more like a compound (you cannot separate the eggs from the flour after baking). The molecular models make abstract chemistry tangible — encourage your child to build as many molecules as they can. The CO vs. CO2 example is powerful for showing how a single atom changes everything. If your child has a molecular model kit, use it; if not, clay and toothpicks work perfectly. This lesson connects to the math curriculum through the subscript numbers in chemical formulas — reading formulas is like reading a mathematical code.

title: Renaissance Art — Michelangelo and the Human Form
description: Students study Michelangelo's approach to sculpting and painting the human body, examining the Sistine Chapel ceiling and the sculpture of David. They practice proportional figure drawing using Michelangelo's principles of anatomy and movement.
instructions:
1. Introduce Michelangelo as sculptor, painter, architect, and poet.
2. Study the Sistine Chapel ceiling: scale, composition, and narrative.
3. Examine the sculpture of David: proportion, contrapposto, emotion.
4. Discuss Michelangelo's study of anatomy for artistic accuracy.
5. Introduce basic figure proportions (the body is 7-8 heads tall).
6. Practice proportional figure sketching.

slides.setup_instructions: Print images of the Sistine Chapel ceiling (especially the Creation of Adam), the David sculpture from multiple angles, and Michelangelo's anatomical sketches. Have rulers ready for measuring proportions.

slides.text: Michelangelo Buonarroti (1475-1564) believed the human body was the most beautiful thing God created. He spent years studying anatomy — even dissecting cadavers — to understand exactly how muscles, bones, and skin work together. This knowledge shows in every figure he painted and sculpted. His humans are not just accurate; they are heroic, powerful, and emotionally alive.

The Sistine Chapel ceiling (1508-1512) covers over 5,000 square feet and contains 343 figures. Michelangelo painted it largely alone, lying on his back on scaffolding for four years. The most famous panel, The Creation of Adam, shows God reaching toward Adam with nearly touching fingers. The composition creates incredible tension — the gap between their fingers is one of the most recognizable images in all of art.

The David (1501-1504) stands 17 feet tall, carved from a single block of marble. Notice the contrapposto pose — David's weight is on one leg, creating a natural, relaxed stance with subtle tension. His oversized hands and intense gaze show a young man preparing to face Goliath. Michelangelo chose to depict the moment before the fight, not after — the moment of courage, not victory. Every artistic choice tells the story.

Figure proportions: The human body is approximately 7-8 heads tall (head height is the unit of measurement). The center of the body is roughly at the hips. Arms reach to mid-thigh. The shoulders are about 2-3 head-widths across. These proportions help artists draw realistic figures. Michelangelo often exaggerated proportions slightly — making hands and torsos larger — to create a sense of heroic power.

slides.prompt: Practice proportional figure drawing. (1) Draw a vertical line and divide it into 8 equal sections (each representing one head-height). Sketch a standing figure using these proportions: head in section 1, chest/torso in sections 2-3, hips at section 4, legs in sections 5-8. (2) Try a contrapposto pose: weight on one leg, opposite shoulder slightly raised. (3) Study the Creation of Adam and sketch just the two hands reaching toward each other, paying attention to the finger positions and the space between them.

slides.text: Michelangelo showed the world what the human form could become in art: powerful, emotional, and heroic. His anatomical knowledge made his art truthful, and his artistic vision made it transcendent. The proportional drawing skills you practiced today are the same principles artists have used for 500 years. Keep practicing — Michelangelo himself said, 'If people knew how hard I worked to get my mastery, it would not seem so wonderful at all.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the student use proportional guidelines to draw a basic human figure? Can they describe contrapposto and explain how Michelangelo's anatomical knowledge improved his art?

parent_notes: Figure drawing is challenging but rewarding. The proportional guidelines (8 heads tall) give students a framework that prevents the common 'big head, small body' problem. Encourage your child to practice drawing figures from reference photos, not from imagination — observation is key. The contrapposto pose appears everywhere in art and even in photography; once your child recognizes it, they will see it in advertisements, statues, and movie poses. Michelangelo's dedication (four years on his back painting the Sistine Chapel) is an inspiring model of persistence. If your child is frustrated with figure drawing, remind them of Michelangelo's own words about hard work.
